thread.title: Luxury handbags power Oroton turnaround
thread.title_full: Luxury handbags power Oroton turnaround | afr.com

author: Catie Low
title: Luxury handbags power Oroton turnaround
text:
Rose Byrne with Oroton's top selling Rose Love X tote bag. by Catie Low Strong sales of Oroton Group's big-ticket handbags are pushing the label back towards profit growth and driving its transformation from a mid-market discounter to an Australian luxury label.
One of its top sellers last financial year was the $1195 limited edition Rose Love X tote, developed in collaboration with the label's glamorous brand ambassador Rose Byrne.
The Rose Love X tote is about double the price of Oroton's core range and chief executive Mark Newman said its popularity revealed the strategy to elevate and rebuild the Oroton brand was working
Ms Byrne is contracted as the face of Oroton for another two years as it works to leverage her celebrity pulling power to attract new customers online and in store.
The brand transformation has come at a cost though, with Oroton's earnings sliding almost 60 per cent to $5.6 million in 2014-15 and its net profit plunged 68 per cent to $2.62 million.
However, comparable sales in Oroton's stores were up 8 per cent in the first seven weeks of this financial year and 24 per cent in the group's three GAP stores. Total group sales were 11 per cent stronger for the same period.
Citi analyst Craig Woolford said it was positive to see the improved sales momentum in the first few weeks of the new financial year but he said the low Australian dollar would be a challenge in the year ahead.
"Oroton Group has dealt with a number of challenges over the past 18 months and is improving the price positioning of its Oroton brand however, the headwinds from the lower currency rates will continue to impact profitability," Mr Woolford said.
 Chief executive Mark Newman said the early sales results were encouraging but it was too early to build any forecasts on them, despite this the business is expected to return to profitable growth in 2016.
He said the decision to end heavy discounting and increase prices had helped the brand but hurt sales in what was a challenging year.
The lower dollar also put pressure on gross margins, which fell by 150 basis points and group net margin declined by 180 basis points as a result of higher purchasing costs.
Oroton claims to be well positioned to ride out the lower dollar for at least the next two years, with hedging in place to cover 85 per cent of US dollar transactions for the next 24 months.
The fashion group's break-up with American retailer Brooks Brothers put an end to the losses stemming from this two-year tie-up.
In 2014-15 the Brooks Brothers losses reached $1.8 million but this was partially offset by a $1.65 million gain on exiting the agreement.
The GAP network doubled in size in fiscal 2015 after Oroton opened three new stores in Sydney, which powered an 81 per cent uplift in sales.
The three established stores were marginally positive in the same period, with sales growth of 0.2 per cent.
A new 'international' fitout concept has been rolled out across about 30 per cent of the Oroton branded store network of to ensure the brand is taking the fight up to international competitors such as Coach and Michael Kors.
By the end of fiscal 2016, at least half the stores will be refurbished and Oroton said the new concept was already driving stronger sales.
Mr Newman said Oroton was keen to expand its international network after opening six new stores in Asia in 2014-15 but but he said the group would do this through partnerships and share the burden of the set-up costs.
Oroton shut down its disappointing Hong Kong and Malaysia stores in the same period and closed its Singaporean regional office.
Oroton declared a full franked final dividend of 2¢ a share and a full year fully franked dividend of 6.5¢ a share.
